body.p:
Ohio.
Washington D. C. June 21" 1864James C. Wetmore O. S. M Agent.
Refers application for the release of Lt Buffum sentenced to 3 years imprisonment for larceny of a pair of boots
War Department
Adjt Genl Office
June 27th 1864
Respectfully referred to the Judge Advocate Genl. for report.

By order of the Secretary of War
(signed) Thos M. Vincent.
Asst. Adjt Genl.

Respectfully submitted to the Secty of War, in connection with the letter of J. R. Dupuy Esqr Commonwealth's Attorney. This letter together with those of Mr. Pittinger & Mrs. Buffum furnishes the only information I have been enabled to obtain, in reference to the offence of late Lieut Buffum notwithstanding the emphatic assertion of Mr. Dupuy that there were no mitigating circumstances in the case, it is at least possible if not probable that as urged by his wife & Mr. Pittinger the crime was committed while the Prisoner was under the influence of liquor That a soldier capabale of such patriotic daring as he had previously
displayed, should with a sword at his side & a commission in his pocket, be capable while in his senses of so petty a theft as this, can scarcely be believed Lt Buffum, while a private soldier, as a member of the expedition organized by Gen Mitchell for cutting the eney's communications, rendered most important services to the government, and rendered them under cirucmstances of extreme peril & prolonged suffering For this he received a medal of honor from the Sercretary of War & a Commission from the Governor of Ohio. His release from his present humiliating confinement
would seem to be but a just appreciation of these services. It is therefore recommended that upon this ground the Governor of Kentucky be requested to pardon him.

(signed) J. Holt
Judge Advocate Genl.
Respectfully submitted to the Secretary of War.
(signed) U. A. Nichols
Asst Adjt Genl.
